text:
Level in Krishnaraja Sagar dips to 85.29 feet; no need to panic, say officials

The dry bed of the Krishnaraja Sagar reservoir, near Srirangapatna, in Karnataka, on Saturday.

Districts in Karnataka dependant on the Cauvery are likely to face an acute shortage of drinking water as the level in the Krishnaraja Sagar (KRS), near Srirangapatna, in Mandya district, dipped to 85.29 feet at 6 a.m. on Saturday. The full-reservoir level (FRL) of KRS is 124.8 ft. The dead storage level is 74 ft.

According to senior officials of the Cauvery Neeravari Nigam Ltd. (CNNL), the storage in the reservoir stood at just 13.31 thousand million cubic feet (tmcft) as against its maximum capacity of 49.45 tmcft. The reservoir had 103 ft. of water on the corresponding day last year. The storage was 25.02 tmcft on March 19, 2015.

The inflow into the KRS was 350 cubic feet per second (cusecs), while the outflow was 3,402 cusecs at 6 a.m. on Saturday.

Of the outflow quantum, over 2,500 cusecs of water are released to protect the standing crops, CNNL officials said. Meanwhile, the CNNL has requested the people to use water judiciously.

Lifeline

There is no need to panic as of now, officials said about the drinking water scarcity in KRS-dependent districts. The monsoon is expected to arrive on time this year. In case of late arrival [of monsoon], the Irrigation Department would draw water, if necessary, from the Hemavathi reservoir in Hassan to meet the drinking water needs of districts dependent on Cauvery, a senior CNNL officer told The Hindu . The reservoir is the lifeline of several districts in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu.

It supplies water to Bengaluru, Mysuru, parts of Bengaluru Rural, Mandya and Ramanagaram districts of Karnataka.
title: Karnataka districts brace for water shortage
